msContents.summary: This papyrus contains the top part of a petition addressed by Philoxenos possibly (far from certain) to the governor of the province of Arcadia. Surviving are (in part) the address (lines 1-4); a short proem (lines 5-8), virtually complete; and the beginning of the narrative of events leading up to the petition (lines 8-13).

msItemStruct.note: Pub. status: Recto; Verso is blank

On palaeographical grounds I should be inclined to assign this piece to the sixth century A.D. The text is written in a large, grand, upright hand, which decreases in thickness by the beginning and apparently in size during the course of line 3. Line 4, from p(ara) on, is written still smaller and with greater slant, evidently by a different hand. The text shows some signs of elegance and has a generally attractive appearance. On the other hand, the writing at the ends of lines 4 and 5 becomes squeezed and cramped, and the text is further marred by a number of mistakes. Judgements as to the numbers of letters missing at the ends of lines 1-3 and 11-12 are exceedingly difficultowing to at least three factors alluded to above. The first hand is larger than the second hand; line 3 is written narrower than lines 1-2; the second hand, in lines 4-5, evidences a tendency toward cramping and squeezing at line ends.

p.note: This light-brown papyrus has been regularly cut off at the top and to the left.Papyrus has also been cut off in the lower left hand and right hand corner as well as in the top right hand corner.

div.ab: (Lines 1-11): "To Flavius John . . . Strategius Julianus . . . Count of the Sacred Consistory (?) and . . . province, from Philoxenos, from the city of Arsinoites.;Inasmuch as all men profit from the pure righteousness of your power, I too seek, with all men, to attain what is just, my case being in the following circumstances:;Fourteen years ago I married my wife Herais and did not stop working at the baker's trade, and the (wages?) from it . . ."
